So I'm very excited
to be here to share the research we have been doing
in the Foundation Interface Lab

at UCSD. I've been very fortunate
to work very closely with my wonderful colleague
Jim Holland, and a bunch

of my amazing PhD students. So in our lab, the
overarching research question

we are exploring is what are
the foundational principles of a productive and convivial
information environment?

And in this environment,
we hope human cognition, digital computation, and
information representations

can be seamlessly integrated. And for the past few
years, of course, a more concrete question,
not surprisingly,

is how will AI transform
our information, activity, and environment. And the title of this talk has
already given the answer away.

So we think the generative,
malleable, and personal user interface is a very
promising direction.

And we are not the only group
of people thinking about this. And as I will try to point out,
this vision for such interface

has been pursued
or being pursued for decades in our community.

So the goal of my talk is
try to share with you guys,

what we have been
imagining, what's the look and feel of such interface, and
what is our current approach

towards it. So if you think about the types
of using different ways of using

AI in our information activity,
there are three main types. One is using this
model to generate

a specific type of content. And this way of
using AI can speed up the process of
information activity by supplying us the
content we need.

Another way of using AI
is through these chatbots. Aside from refining or writing
or help you draft an email,

one thing that's
really interesting is how it can help with
exploratory information activities, such as
understanding a new domain

through a series of Q&A. Now, of course,
chatbot is very limited because many complex
information activities require

diverse sources of information
and different functionality. And that's why probably the
agentic workflow seems just more

compelling. Anthropic releases computer
use in our demonstration, and recently OpenAI's operator.

And these AI agents can
receive a user's request and then manipulate the apps
or browser on your computer.

And I think this is a
remarkable tech achievement. But I think this approach
has a serious problem.

And if we are going
down this path, we will not be able to fully
leverage human cognition and AI

to achieve productive
information activity. Now, before I take an
HCI perspective on this,

let's take a historical view on
this problem or this phenomenon. Because I think the computer
use demonstration and the OpenAI

operator is the perfect
example of what we used to say, or Mark Twain used to say,
"History doesn't repeat itself,

but often rhymes." So the Stanford audience should
know this example really well.

Back in the first
Industrial Revolution, the steam engine was
the main power source.

And each factory will have--
they had this one steam engine that drive the entire factory.

So basically through the axles
or on the ceiling and also

the belts and pulleys,
there's one steam engine is able to drive all
these individual machines on the floor.

And so when you're
designing the factory, you have to consider how
the power is delivered.

The machine that
needed the most power must be positioned very
close to the power source, because if it's very
far, the axle will be

broken because of the torque. So basically, the
layout of the factory is designed to accommodate
the power delivery mechanism.

And electricity drove the
second Industrial Revolution. And so what people did?

So Erik Brynjolfsson
and Andrew McAfee found that people
simply just bought the largest electric motors
and replaced the steam engine.

They just put it
where it used to be. They didn't change
the factory layout. They didn't change how
things are manufactured.

And as a result, the
productivity barely improved for over 30 years.

And it was only-- things were only changed
when new layout was designed or new manufacturing
workflow were introduced,

and the productivity
skyrocketed. So what's so critical
about these layout?

Well, the layout
or the new workflow meets the natural
workflow of the material.

So let's take a look at our
graphical user interface now. If just for the
sake of metaphor,

let's consider this application
based graphical user interface to be the first UI revolution.

And with this kind of design,
we are the power source that drives each individual
app to achieve our information

activity.  And if you actually compare
this with the factory,

it's quite similar. Each individual app is kind
of an individual machine. And they work together to
help you achieve the activity.

And instead of
just manufacturing physical materials, we're
producing digital materials.

So what are we
doing now with AI? Well, those computer
use demonstration

is basically trying to
replace human with AI. Right now, AI is
the power source

that drive these machines. So we're substituting
human with AI. Now, if we take a
page from history,

we probably should think
about how we should redesign this information environment. And actually, you don't need
to take the page from history.

There has been a lot
of evidence in HCI that argues the
application-centric information

paradigm is not very conducive
to complex information activity. So Bonnie Nardi, who
studied extensively

how human uses computer to
accomplish information activity summarize really well. She said, "The traditional
information interface paradigm

does not support the complexity,
flexibility, or sociality of human activity,
and argues that we

should move beyond the rigidity
of separate applications or file and folder system.

Now, to figure out how we
should really move beyond, I think we need to
answer three questions. One is, what is the
natural workflow

of information activity? And the second is, why has the
application-centric information

interface paradigm failed
to achieve this workflow? And third is, what's
different this time with AI?

So let's dive into
these questions. Now, there has been a lot of
work in HCI that study how human

engage with
information activity. And hats off to
these seminal works. And if I ask you maybe one
phrase you will come up

to describe the workflow of
information activity could maybe it's this
iterative process of collecting, processing,
and editing information.

So I think this
statement is true, but not very helpful
for two reasons.

First, I think the
word "iterative," which we often use in HCI,
is really sugarcoating

the complexity of human
information activity. And also, I don't
think it really

reveals the key reason
why we have to go through this messy process. So I think the human information
activity or some people

also have this thought is
that the human information activity is very dynamic. It's actually a very
chaotic process.

You need to find all kinds
of information sources, try to determine which
one is useful or not, and then revise your goal,
form a new understanding,

and then go find other things. And I think another aspect that
we should talk more is personal.

And what I mean by
that is when you engage with
information activity, you have a specific goal.

You are trying to look for a
specific piece of information. And it's so unique that no
single source of information

out there will meet your goal. So you have to find a
lot of different sources, try to piece things together
to meet your information need.

And same for applications. You may want to
process information or see information
in a certain way,

but there hasn't been-- there is
no applications out there that meets your specific need. So if we step back a
little bit and look

at how there is what the
mismatch is, so basically in an application or
maybe a web page even,

is a specific system that
developed by a specific group of developer. They somehow develop
this understanding

of how they think user-- what the user would need. And they're correct
for the most part.

And they propose this
specific user interface that contains
specific information and provides specific
functionality.

A user under a very
specific context, they may actually have a
slightly different goal.

They may want a slightly
different interface, and they may want different
pieces of information and functionality.

So this is also true just
collecting information. The author of their
article couldn't

predict what kind of information
needs the readers will want.

So David Karger phrase
this really well. He said that no
developer can predict

all the ways a user will want to
record, annotate, and manipulate information.

So here's an example
for you guys. So this is the Airbnb app. I use it a lot to find a
place to stay when I travel.

Now, when I look
for places to stay, I care about both the
price and the rating.

But if you look
at the interface, there's no rating on the map. For me to see the rating, I have
to click on each individual one,

and then the detail view will
show the map-- show the rating. And you may say, well, there's
a hard design trade-off.

There's not much
space on the map. We can't display too much. All right, OK.

Well, another factor
that I consider is I usually want to
travel with my dogs. I have two dogs, so
I want to make sure

the place I'm going, whether
they're pet-friendly so that I can consider whether
I will bring my dogs.

But to find that detail on this
interface, right now you can't. The developer decides
that for this entity,

the information
that user should see is the price rating,
number of reviews,

whether it's free
cancellation or not, or the style of the room. But I just care about
whether it's pet-friendly. So I have to dive
into this detail,

get into another detail page to
be able to find that feature.

So this is what
I'm talking about. Yes, you have a question. Yes. So I'm curious how
you see filters then.

Yes. So here, yeah, I understand
your question, is like, what if I can select a
pet-friendly as a filter?

But I haven't decided
whether I will because I need to consider all these factors. So what I want is
whether there's a place

maybe it has a
dog-friendly icon. There could be places
that do not have it. But if you use the filter,
all the other things

are filtered out. So this is exactly
what I'm talking about. The software, yes, they
provide some kind of ways

for you to get there, but
not exactly what you want. So here's another example.

This may be-- So like the developer
of this website determines what
information you need.

As a student, you may be curious
about the faculty's office hours. You may care about
their research area.

Well, you have to dive
into each individual one to find that detail. So let's zoom out a little bit.

I think our pioneer,
Douglas Engelbart, pointed out this
problem really well, is that the augmentation means,
if we see the information

system, we sort of
design these system based on our understanding of
a large statistical population,

and no attempts have been made
to fit the individual needs. And to develop a system
that really, I mean,

he was trying to
augment human intellect, the system should
provide opportunity for significant adoption
of the individual,

to the individual's
characteristics. Though I think one thing
that's really interesting is he pointed out this problem
before digital applications were

even invented, before
even personal computer. And I think fundamentally, this
really isn't an HCI problem.

It is kind of an
economic problem. It is just more
economic to abstract the common needs of
a large population

and develop reusable
solutions for them instead of trying to develop
a really customized solution

for each individual user. And it's really for this reason
that there's no grant writing

or research proposal app. There is no family travel app. There's no organizing a dinner
party app because everybody

does it differently. It's just not economic
to make an app that way. So then what do we have?

Well, we have rigid apps
that developers think, OK, here's how you should use it. Or we have bloated apps.

One way to support
all the users' needs, just like let's dump
all the things they could

potentially need into one app. And then it becomes a super
complex app that you cannot use.

So that's at the
application level. What about the activity level? If you think about how app
is developed, the developer,

they prioritize optimizing the
user experience within the app. But the operating
system, who's supposed

to provide more structure for
us to coordinate our activity, what do they provide? Virtual desktop or
another just like--

But then the user
actually, when they need to work on these
information activity, they need to coordinate
a lot of applications.

So for example, research find
that data science workers need to juggle 13
categories of applications

in their daily work. Now, and also, like when I'm
working on my research grant-- Well, I don't have an app.

I have a lot of apps. And I have to juggle all these
things to achieve my activity.

Same for organizing
a dinner party. And you may use a
different set of app. And that's the whole point.

We all have our own workflow. So at the end of
the day, we suffer

from very fragmented workflow
and a really challenging information management. And just on a daily basis,
we have messy desktop

and tab explosion. So I think this is the problem
of the application-centric

interface paradigm. We have rigid containers
and bloated containers. We have fragmented workflow
and challenging information
management. But now, we have AI. Things should be better.

So let's take a look. So last week, last
weekend, I got my hands onto OpenAI Operator.

I paid $200 to be
able to use it. And I was trying to
cast a wizard case

of organizing a dinner party
because it was the Chinese New Year. So I opened it.

Here's my interaction with it. So I started with I'm thinking
about organizing a dinner party.

So they reply with
these chat messages, like here are the things
you should think about. I'm like, cool. That's useful.

I probably will start
thinking about the menu. So I followed up with Operator.

And Operator asked me about
my preferences, so I replied.

And then it gave me
this initial menu.

So I was curious. So I was like, OK, give me
the recipes of these menu. Then the Operator goes ahead
and does its kind of job.

It opens this browser already. And so it will just copy
the text from the chat,

search the recipes online. And this is sped
up like five times. So it's just doing
all these browsing.

And then after I think 5
minutes or maybe 4 minutes, it returned sort of this
list of menus and the recipes

with links. So I wasn't very happy with
the menu, to be honest.

But I was just trying
to keep it going to see where things will break, right? So I asked it to generate
a list of ingredients.

And I also want it
to help me check whether these ingredients
are in store, for example, in Costco or Whole Foods.
So I basically give this prompt. And then I went to grab lunch.

And by the time I come
back, it was still working. And I felt so bad. I was like, think
about the trees

that are being burned
by the Operator and the water that's
being used to cool it. So I mean, it was just running.

It's just so long. So I had to pause it. So otherwise, maybe
it just runs forever. So I paused it.

And so I looked
into this, right? So what was the problem? So I opened the
dropdown list, where

you can see all its operations. So here is just
a tiny bit of it. And I mean, we are all
from computer science.

One of the reason
things don't end is just somehow got
into a weird loop. So basically,
operators somehow start

to loop itself over this
subset of ingredients for unknown reasons.

So I paused it. Then I just, whatever,
I move on, right? So the next thing I ask is I
want to get recommendations

for a few bottled wines because
I want to treat my guests well. And replied, I'm unable
to help with this.

I mean, the first time,
I was like, wait, wait. What's going on? Why? And here's my
response-- his response.

So I was like, I
think I understand why, but then there's nothing
I can do about it, right? Just give me the same response.

So I accept the reality,
and then I move on. So the next thing I ask is
like, well, let's move on

to the activity after dinner. Any recommendations? And then operator become
cheerful again and then give me recommendations about
board games and whatever.

So I also had a few other
interactions with it, what board games would be
suitable for a group of 10?

How do I set a doodle up
to coordinate with them? So after four hours,
I still wasn't

able actually to get
to the dinner plan that I was happy with, but I
was very exhausted because I had

to do a bunch of
screen recordings and a lot of stuff and
waiting and then checking. And I think maybe the OpenAI
operator was exhausted too.

So here's what the interface
looked like when I stopped. What did you notice?

I still got a browser
exploded with tabs. And there is also this very,
very, very long chat history.

So then where is my dinner plan? Well, there is no
concrete form of it.

It's somewhere in this chat. It's somewhere in
all these tabs. And this interface is kind
of the same as before.

or iterate on this activity. So wouldn't it be great if I
have this environment, where

it can aggregate only
the relevant information and functionality
but also provide

really effective organization
and representation of overall activity? So this is what
the HCI community

has been calling the
activity-centered interface paradigm or
activity-centered computing.

Now, before large
language model, this was actually really tricky
because to achieve this really

personal environment,
you need to be able to create an environment
that support any user's information activity.

They may be of any
domains, any complexity, and their goal may change
just during the activity.

The goal may shift, like shift. So how do we approach
maybe with the help of AI?

Well, the current approach
is let's just generate the sequence of actions right
on top of the existing paradigm.

What we were trying
to think is would it be possible to actually
generate a good environment

and then have actions
running on top of it? So we took a specification-based
based approach.

Basically, when a
user gave a prompt, like I'm thinking about
organizing a dinner party, it will first generate
what kind of organization

you may need for
organizing a dinner party. And then it will map
those things to a UI.

And then the UI will be
rendered as this environment. So let me give you some example.

Imagine I'm thinking of
organizing a dinner party. You may care about
people, location, time,

and the UI specification will
tell you or guide the system,

like OK, what's the
level of detail? What's the representation? And what's the
interface organization that you may want to use?

And then it will generate, put
the right elements together. Now you may have new needs or
new desire for your activity.

And if you have
followup prompts, it will try to change the
activity specification like dishes, ingredients,
or food restrictions

when you are thinking
about the menu. And then the activity
environment will change. So you have this
graphical user interface,

that GUI-based
activity environment. So basically, this
pipeline works this, right?

When the user have a
prompt on their data, the activity specification
will guide the system, like OK,

what are the information
entities we provide? What is the structure
among this activity? And the UI specification
will basically

guide the system to
choose the right UI and then compose
everything together.

So on top of that,
we also want user to be able to directly
manipulate the activity

specification, so
that I can further adjust the UI based
on my needs because I know I will make errors right.

And I also want to be able
to adjust the UI, right? So I want to be able to
adjust the overall information environment, but I also want to
be able to adjust individual UI

elements. And then eventually,
hopefully, I will have generated malleable
and personal activity
environment. So does this work? So we have this pipeline.

And like will it actually
generate something useful? So my PhD student Reema
built this system, Jelly,

which explores this pipeline and
the efficacy of this pipeline. So I'm going to play a 4-minute
video of some user using Jelly

to achieve a
information activity. So let's take a look.

Let's look at how
Millie uses the system Jelly to help her relocate for
a new job in San Francisco.
She opens Jelly. I'm moving to San Francisco.

However, Jelly
thinks she's trying to figure out a moving plan,
so provides her with moving services and a budget.

She deletes the fields she
doesn't need and further prompts. I'm finding a place to live.
Tell me about different areas.

I've heard some of
them could be sketchy.

To support Millie reviewing
how safe each area is, Jelly adds the safety level
and relevant information

to each area. To better compare
these areas, she transformed the
structure into a table

and ranks the areas
by safety level. She definitely doesn't want
to live in this area and this.

Commute time is also an
important factor for her.
She tells Jelly-- My company is on Market Street. How does the commute look like?

Jelly adds her company
in the home panel and the commute time for
each area in the table.

It also suggests the two areas
with the shortest commute time. Seeing this, Millie
narrows her option down

to Nob Hill and
Mission District. She then asked Jelly--

What are the apartments
in those areas? Jelly then presents
available apartments

on the map with the details
relevant to her interests, such as safety level
and commute time.

After some
exploration, Millie has

her short list of apartments. A few days later,
the hiring manager

tells Millie that she
also has the option to work at the New York office. So she opens jelly and
changes the location

from San Francisco to New York. Everything updates
automatically,

and she can reuse the structures
for her decision making. Millie decides that she prefers
the San Francisco office.

After she moves in, she
wants to throw a dinner party to celebrate her new
job and new home.

She tells Jelly-- I'm hosting a dinner
party with my friends.

Instead of directly
generating the space, Jelly asks, who are
you going to invite? And then present
her contact list.

Millie selects Alice,
Mike, and Sarah. Jelly then asks,
when is the party?

And presents a calendar. Looks like next Friday
night would be a good time.

With these details, Jelly
then generates a home panel displaying the guests,
menu, and activities.

She reveals the dishes
suggested for her and realizes some of
them are not suitable.

Alice and I are both vegan. To accommodate this, Jelly
adds a dietary preference

to all the guests, updates
the existing dishes, and adds a dietary suitability
property for all the dishes.

With the connections established
by the underlying schema, Jelly updates the dishes that
don't meet the restrictions.

Millie deletes some of them,
and asks for more options.

Seeing these, she also realizes
Sarah prefers gluten-free food.

Having figured out the

Jelly generates a
shopping plan which

contains a list of

needs to buy at each store.

While Millie is shopping,

Of course.  She adds David to
the guest list,

and the dishes and ingredients
are updated accordingly.

Looks like it will
be a fun party.  All right.

So that's the Jelly system. I know maybe the
text is too small and the video is
probably too fast. This thing will be
online very soon.

Then you can take a look later. But I just want to
step back and compare these different
approaches, right?

The current approach
is try to generate these sequence of actions right
on top of existing interface.

And at the end, you have
these really messy information environment, and you don't know
where your activity really is.

Whereas our approach is trying
to generate the activity environment using these
underlying activity

specification. And the AI can automate things
on top of this environment, and the user can engage
with the environment

directly to achieve
their information needs. So let's break down the
system just a little

bit to help you
understand maybe how the system works, and there's a
bunch of details in the paper.

But basically, this interface
has three views, right? There's this activity
specification,

the user prompt region,

In a future system,
you can imagine the activity specification

or the prompt region can just

And so the system
worked this way, right? When I have a prompt, it
will generate this activity

specification. It's just the model of
the activity, right? The overall structure. And based on that, we will
generate the graphical user

interface. So the way we generate things
is based on the type of data in the activity specification.

So for example, for destination,

For the different areas,

One as this card and

together. But basically, the
idea is that we have this generative

And in the future, we can

And another part that Jelly

And what we did is we have this

for us to test the

UI, this UI do not

have the most

can click on each item.

And then see the

What about the apartment type? What about the moving date? What about whether

here. So clearly, there are some
limitation of the Jelly system. Oh, here's another one.

What if I don't want the

is my preference, right? So what we really want is a

that can describe really high

to be both AI operable,

so that AI can specify
here is the right UI configuration for
you to have the UI,

but also end user manipulable,

So how do we
approach this thing? How do we describe the just
like numerous UIs out there?

So we are quite inspired
by the work that's done by Christopher
Alexander's work

on pattern language
for architecture. And this line of work
has actually huge impact

on software engineering and
already on user interfaces. People have been coming
up design patterns for developing softwares
and good user interfaces.

So what is a pattern? Well, according to
Alexander's notion, each pattern
describes the problem,

which occurs over and over
again in the environment, and then describe the core
solution to the problem.

And in such a way that you can
use a solution a million times over without doing it
twice the same way.

That's super appealing, right? I mean, that's what we want. We want to have some
way of generating UI,

but we want it to be able to
adapt to each individual user. So how do we achieve that?

Well, he said, well,
you need to identify the invariant in this problem. You want to identify the common
property among these problems.

And then based on
those properties, you can vary a bunch of things. So in HCI, as I
mentioned, we have

been trying to build upon this
notion of design patterns, and we have a lot of
work in this area.

Even practitioners, like this is
Apple's design guide for-- these are the patterns
that Apple promotes.

But traditionally,
these patterns need to be carried out
by human designers. What we want is we want
this pattern to be AI

operable and user manipulable. So what are all the
patterns out there?

If we can identify
all these patterns and make them more
operationalizeable,

potentially we can achieve
this technical pipeline. So we looked into one specific
pattern which we call,

which is the overview
detail pattern. So this is one project
we recently did.

So if you don't know about
the overview detail pattern, it's this pattern that's
just super simple.

It has two views. One overview, which shows a
bunch of information entities, and a detail view,
which gives you detail

information about what entity. But it served this
very essential need when you're in the
information activity.

You want to browse a
large amount of things, and then you want to
dive into specific ones. And for this reason, the
overview detail pattern

is just everywhere. When you shop on Amazon, the
search result returns overview.

You dive into it, you
get a detailed view. Airbnb is an overview. Detail pattern
follows that pattern.

The map is an overview. Each card is a detail. But there is more detail views
behind if you click into it.

Booking a flight, your email
